author: By Michael Crowley
title: Bill Richardson Reveled in Role of Freelance Envoy to Dictators
description: The former New Mexico governor and ambassador to the U.N. filled a specialized diplomatic niche, talking to strongmen when presidents and other officials could — or would — not.
content: It was days before Russia invaded Ukraine in February 2022, and the U.S. government was urging Americans to stay away from Russia. That’s when Bill Richardson boarded a plane to Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China to Its People: Spies Are Everywhere, Help Us Catch Them
description: As Beijing tries to enlist the “whole of society” to guard against foreign enemies, the line between vigilance and paranoia fades.
content: Beijing sees forces bent on weakening it everywhere: embedded in multinational companies, infiltrating social media, circling naïve students. And it wants its people to see them, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
title: Why Did a Drug Gang Kill 43 Students? Text Messages Hold Clues.
description: The Mexican police, military officers and others secretly colluded with a cartel that kidnapped 43 students, a case unsolved after nearly a decade. Wiretaps show just how much the authorities helped the cartel behind the mass abduction, and what led to it.
content: It is perhaps Mexico’s most notorious cold case — 43 college students shot at by the police, forced into patrol cars, handed over to a drug cartel and never seen again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: A Crackdown on Free Speech in One of the Freer Corners of the Mideast
description: A satirical Arabic website, much like The Onion, poked fun at a royal wedding in Jordan in June. Not long after, it was blocked. “We’re totally backsliding,” said one cartoonist in the kingdom.
content: The lavish wedding of Jordan’s crown prince this spring was breathlessly anticipated for months in the kingdom’s state media, and when it arrived, it did not disappoint. After days of public festivities, celebrities and royalty decked out in designer clothing swanned about an opulent palace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lily Meyer
title: In Chile, a Quest for Truth Driven by Survivor’s Guilt
description: Ariel Dorfman’s novel “The Suicide Museum” uses the controversy around a president’s death to examine personal and collective grief.
content: On Sept. 11, 1973, President Salvador Allende of Chile died inside the national palace in Santiago during a U.S.-backed military coup led by General Augusto Pinochet. Afterward, the Chilean army announced that suicide was the official cause of death, which many Chileans distrusted, if not flatly rejected. But in 1990, after 17 years of authoritarian rule in which any challenge to the junta’s line was dangerous, Pinochet lost power, and the nature of Allende’s death swiftly became a public question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Nicholas Nehamas
title: In Florida, Even a Hurricane Can’t Sweep Away Presidential Politics
description: President Biden arrived in Florida to tour an area hit by Hurricane Idalia, but Gov. Ron DeSantis, a potential rival for the presidency, was a no-show.
content: President Biden offered his support and condolences to a Florida community hit hard by Hurricane Idalia after being snubbed by Ron DeSantis, the state’s Republican governor and a potential rival for the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Grabar
title: We’re Taking New York City’s Streets Back — and Then We’re Coming for the Rest of the Country
description: The fight over congestion pricing gets at something so very much bigger.
content: Over the summer, New York’s Metropolitan Transportation Authority held meetings to discuss how to organize its congestion pricing toll for drivers entering Manhattan south of 60th Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: For Politicians, Vacations Can Be a Lot of Work
description: Taking a break from the campaign trail is risky. History is littered with cautionary tales of candidates who got it wrong.
content: Labor Day weekend, once the official kickoff of campaign season, now comes almost a year after most candidates have hit the trail and after the first primary debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: ‘Jamaica Mistaica’: Jimmy Buffett Song Inspired After Plane Sprayed by Gunfire
description: In 1996, the police in Jamaica mistook Buffett for a drug smuggler after he landed his seaplane with the singer Bono and others on board and opened fire on it.
content: Jimmy Buffett’s life evokes images of boozy chill-outs by the beach and a certain carefree calm, but in 1996 the singer’s seaplane came under a hail of gunfire in a dramatic encounter with the Jamaican authorities that inspired a song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Frank and Marcelo Gleiser
title: The Story of Our Universe May Be Starting to Unravel
description: Is cosmology in crisis?
content: Not long after the James Webb Space Telescope began beaming back from outer space its stunning images of planets and nebulae last year, astronomers, though dazzled, had to admit that something was amiss. Eight months later, based in part on what the telescope has revealed, it’s beginning to look as if we may need to rethink key features of the origin and development of the universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is It ‘Prostitution’ or ‘Sex Work’?
description: Readers respond to a column by Pamela Paul about how the term “sex work” legitimizes the exploitative sex trade.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Shows That Give Off Pleasure, and a Bit of Body Heat
description: Roberta Smith, co-chief art critic, on fall exhibitions at the Met, MoMA, Whitney, Folk Art Museum and more that she’s looking forward to.
content: Among the fall’s surveys of contemporary art, I’m most excited about “Made in L.A. 2023: Acts of Living,” (Oct. 1 -Dec. 31) the sixth incarnation of the Hammer Museum’s always enlightening biennial survey of Los Angeles-area art. Its illustrated checklist — all there is to go on before a show actually opens — is palpable with hand making and color. It has body heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilan Stavans
title: Yiddish Is Having a Moment
description: The language has been experiencing something of a revival.
content: For a language without a physical address that has come frighteningly close to extinction, Yiddish’s will to live seems inexhaustible. The lesson is simple and straightforward: Survival is an act of stubbornness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Bill Richardson, Champion of Americans Held Overseas, Dies at 75
description: After serving in Congress and as governor of New Mexico, he practiced quasi-public and freelance diplomacy, often with considerable success.
content: Bill Richardson, who served two terms as governor of New Mexico and 14 years as a congressman, then continued to devote himself to liberating Americans who were being held hostage or who he believed were being wrongfully detained by hostile countries overseas, died on Friday at his summer home in Chatham, Mass., on Cape Cod. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Cody Rigsby Needs Dessert. And Cheetos. And Drag Queens.
description: The Peloton instructor and author of “XOXO, Cody” is a big believer in the power of a cold plunge and sticking with therapy even when things are going well.
content: Fans of Cody Rigsby’s Peloton classes, and there are legions, know he’ll spin them ragged. But the spicy banter he dispenses from his cycle has the effect of numbing the pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Summer’s Not Over Yet
description: Labor Day weekend marks the unofficial end of summer. But we don’t have to be so doctrinaire about it.
content: This weekend, while you’re working the grill or attending a parade or sitting in traffic, conversation will turn, inevitably, to the end of summer. How fast it’s gone by, someone will remark, always incredulous. You’ll nod along and say something wistful about how you could smell a crispness in the air this morning, or how few weeks are left of good tomatoes. Someone will wail about having seen silos of candy corn looming large and in charge at the supermarket and the next thing you know, it’s fall. Time to put on long pants and real shoes, time to straighten up and fly right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Fans Remember Jimmy Buffett, ‘a Poet of Paradise’
description: Mr. Buffett’s fandom was wide-ranging: Notables from politics, sports and the arts now look back fondly on the singer’s life and career.
content: After it was announced on Friday that the singer and songwriter Jimmy Buffett had died, a wave of tributes came from his lifelong fans, including presidents, actors and at least one sports team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: How Do I Make My Landlord Clean the Basement — Without Angering Him?
description: Garbage left in basement common areas can attract rats and create fire hazards. But getting landlords to respond isn’t always easy.
content: Q: We are tenants in a market-rate rental building on the Upper West Side. The laundry machines are in the basement, which is a common area. The problem is that the basement is stuffed with junk — which I was willing to put up with, but now I’ve seen a rat nosing around. There’s a full-size couch that’s been left for months, a broken-down air-conditioner on the floor, an extension cord coiled around the pipes, and a knife block filled with knives sitting on the electric meter. It’s unclear where all this stuff came from. Besides the rats, I’m worried that the junk is a fire hazard. I’ve called 311 to make a complaint, but what else can be done?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
title: A Brutal Path Forward, Village by Village
description: As Ukraine pushes slowly forward in its counteroffensive, it’s relying heavily on the effort of hundreds of small-scale assault groups, each tasked with attacking a single trench, tree line or house.
content: The mission for the Ukrainian unit was to take a single house, in a village that is only a speck on the map but was serving as a stronghold for Russian soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joel Wolfram and Colbi Edmonds
title: Manhunt for Pennsylvania Fugitive Narrows to Area Near Prison
description: As the authorities continued their search on Saturday, they said video from surveillance cameras suggested he was hiding close by.
content: With the aid of video footage from residential surveillance cameras, authorities on Saturday narrowed their manhunt for a convicted murderer who escaped from a prison outside Philadelphia, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Fire Department’s Program To Protect Homes From Wildfires
description: Nelson, British Columbia, is one of several places in western Canada asking homeowners to make changes, and sometimes it’s funding them.
content: Shortly before the current wildfires moved toward Kelowna in British Columbia, I traveled there, and to other points in the province, to report on programs that can give communities a fighting chance at protecting homes and other buildings, and that allow residents to safely flee when fires arrive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russia Says It Thwarted Another Ukrainian Attack on Crimea Bridge
description: Russia’s Ministry of Defense said it had destroyed three sea drones targeting the Kerch Strait Bridge, a vital supply line for Moscow’s forces that links occupied Crimea to Russia.
content: The Russian military said Saturday that it had thwarted another attack on a critical bridge linking the occupied Crimean Peninsula to Russia that Kyiv has vowed to keep attacking until it is unusable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Caroline Wozniacki Is Getting Very Good at Comebacks
description: Wozniacki keeps finding magic at the U.S. Open, but she’s not the only player enjoying a revival. Stan Wawrinka and Elina Svitolina also can’t find the exits.
content: America likes to fancy itself the land of second chances. Show some humility. Work hard. A new you, or perhaps a better version of the old you, is just around the corner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Mujib Mashal
title: India Launches Its First Solar Mission
description: The goal is to study the sun’s outer layers, to better understand its physics and dynamics and to improve understanding of space weather.
content: A little over a week after successfully landing a rover on the moon, India on Saturday launched its first solar mission aimed at studying the outer layers of the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 2, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 2, 2023
content: An article on Friday about the one-handed backhand in tennis omitted a prominent player in the U.S. Open who made it to the third round and who uses a one-handed backhand. He is Daniel Evans. (Stan Wawrinka and Grigor Dimitrov are the others.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Should Right-Wing Populists Despair?
description: What Sohrab Ahmari’s doubts say about his former cause — and about the economy and culture.
content: Over the last few weeks Sohrab Ahmari, well known as a leading intellectual exponent of a combative Trumpian conservatism, has been making the rounds explaining why he’s giving up on right-wing populism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Cross-Cultural Exchanges from Vietnam, Ethiopia, the Caribbean
description: Solo shows also abound, from Charles Gaines to Harry Smith, while the women of Land Art and Fluxus keep rocking in major exhibitions.
content: Big, globe-leaping historical art shows are still scarce, post-pandemic. But the Metropolitan Museum of Art persists in doing them, and no one does big and global better. I have high expectations for “Africa and Byzantium” (Nov. 19-March 3, 2024), a roots-and-routes exhibition that promises to illuminate cultural exchanges made between medieval African kingdoms in Egypt, Nubia, and Ethiopia and the Byzantine Empire across the Mediterranean. There are sure to be surprises and beauties beyond compare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: Grief and Remembrance, Day After Day
description: Four days after the attacks of Sept. 11, The New York Times began printing short profiles of the victims. The series became known as Portraits of Grief.
content: Few New York Times projects have sparked so many emotional responses as “Portraits of Grief.” These brief profiles depicted 2,310 victims of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, or about three out of every four who were killed. They were not dry résumés but flesh-and-blood stories of parents, spouses, siblings, children, cousins, lovers, partners, fiancés, friends, neighbors and colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: Rest Stop
description: Nine reporters. Two days. One rest stop on the New York State Thruway.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Is New York City’s Lanternfly Killing Spree Working?
description: The infestation of invasive spotted lanternflies is leveling off in some parts of the city, and growing in others. Officials are urging New Yorkers to keep killing them.
content: There are many ways to kill a spotted lanternfly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: ‘Overachieving’ Tropical Storm Katia Is Expected to Continue Weakening
description: Its direction is hard to predict, forecasters said, but it poses no threat to land, and its sustained winds have dropped to 45 miles per hour.
content: Forecasters on Saturday described Tropical Storm Katia as “overachieving” in the Eastern Atlantic, saying that though its direction was proving difficult to pin down, it was expected to weaken on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Murphy
title: When Financial Independence Isn’t Always the Goal
description: Many Iranian Americans say their families place a high premium on education — sometimes at the expense of early financial independence — potentially complicating their financial futures.
content: In the summer of 1996, when I was 16, some of my friends found jobs at our local mall in Jacksonville, Fla. We all came from upper-middle-class families, so working was about building character and earning spending money, not because of financial necessity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T.M. Brown
title: How the Executive Editor of Sports Illustrated Spends His Sundays
description: L. Jon Wertheim cherishes an hour of writing without distractions at a local diner and a weekly trip to Trader Joe’s.
content: In his nearly three decades at Sports Illustrated before becoming executive editor, the journalist L. Jon Wertheim bounced all over the world of sports, covering mixed martial arts, the N.B.A., sports psychology and pool hall hustlers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: Two Documentaries on School Integration Offer New Views of an Old Problem
description: Premiering in September, the films take very different looks at what has and hasn’t changed in the almost 70 years since Brown v. Board of Education.
content: You most likely know that the landmark 1954 Supreme Court decision Brown v. Board of Education ruled that racial segregation in U.S. public schools was unconstitutional. You may also know that the decision ordered states to desegregate “with all deliberate speed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: What the Contradiction of Slavery Tells Us About Abortion Rights
description: When states have radically different laws, American life is unsettled.
content: One of the ironies of the American slave system was that it depended for its survival on a federal structure that left it vulnerable and unstable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Another Ethnic Cleansing Could Be Underway — and We’re Not Paying Attention
description: Azerbaijan is blockading the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, and people are dying.
content: With its Russian torture chambers and slaughter of civilians, the war in Ukraine is horrifying enough. But what if another country is taking advantage of the distraction to commit its own crimes against humanity?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The Tennis Education of Ben Shelton
description: The late-blooming 20-year-old is a rising star thanks to a blistering serve that he is learning to balance with the rest of his game.
content: At the packed grandstand court here on Friday, you could hear the fans’ murmured conversation, a low, languid hush, as Ben Shelton toed the line to serve for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: The Glamorous, Lonely Lives of Private Chefs
description: More cooks are pursuing careers in cooking for wealthy clients, but the glitz that makes it into viral TikTok videos isn’t always the whole picture.
content: In July, Tashea Channell Younge, a private chef and caterer from New York City, flew to Los Angeles, all expenses paid, to cook a private dinner in a luxurious kitchen for 15 people. She then cooked for the N.F.L. wide receiver Noah Brown and some teammates. Later that month, she was back in New York for a candlelit private dinner on the waterfront, complete with rose petals and a view of the Empire State Building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Klingener
title: In Key West, Where Buffett Met His Muse, the Tributes Flow
description: On Saturday, the island that inspired him, and grew in fame because of him, celebrated a life and a way of life.
content: A small shrine of flowers appeared in front of Margaritaville in Key West, Fla., on Saturday. There were more flowers outside Shrimp Boat Sound, Jimmy Buffett’s low-key recording studio along the docks of the Historic Seaport, where fans of the singer also placed a six-pack of beer, a copy of one of his books and, of course, a shaker of salt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Computer Games
description: Dylan Schiff makes a state-of-the-art Sunday puzzle debut.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivienne Walt and Lauren Hirsch
title: The Disruptive Power of Weight Loss Drugs Is Being Felt Beyond Pharma
description: Retailers, the makers of foods marketed for weight loss, and other types of companies could see knock-on effects from the rise of diabetes and weight loss drugs like Ozempic.
content: As they do every summer, publicly traded companies posted their second-quarter results while Americans were baring their bodies on the beach. But this year, the timing was apt. On several earnings calls in August, chief executives reassured investors that the Ozempic revolution had not left them in the dust, and that they could somehow share in the blazing success of new diabetes and weight loss drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: America Is Using Up Its Groundwater
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 2, 2023.
content: “Most of the water we’re pulling out of the ground is thousands of years old. It’s not like it rains on Monday, and by Saturday it’s in the aquifer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: ‘I’d Do It Again!’
description: Rebecca Goldstein’s Saturday debut bursts with buried treasures.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Rebecca Goldstein has been contributing puzzles to The Times for less than two years; they have all had themes, so far, and they have all been memorable, like a hidden-monster Monday grid and, most recently, a “big shoes to fill” Sunday collaboration with Rafael Musa. This is her themeless debut, and it’s one of those puzzles with long entries so bright and engaging that they form a loose motif of standout terms, most making their first appearance in the Crossword. They’re clued well enough to make for a happy and challenging solve, and many of them are loaded with enough interesting pop culture subtext to be provocative even after you figure them out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Team Isn’t Waiting for Impeachment to Go on the Offensive
description: The White House has enlisted two dozen attorneys, legislative liaisons and others to craft strategies in the face of Republican threats to charge the president with high crimes and misdemeanors.
content: Just before 8 p.m. on Thursday, Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene posted a video of herself at a town hall in her Georgia district declaring that she “will not vote to fund the government” unless the House holds a vote to open an impeachment inquiry against President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Anxiety in the Age of Barbie
description: Young women in crisis are wondering, “What was I made for?”
content: It was “the summer of girl power,” a tour de force by a glittering troika. With pink dream houses, songs and sequins, Barbie, Taylor Swift and Beyoncé buoyed the economy and sent women’s confidence soaring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Jimmy Buffett, Roguish Bard of Island Escapism, Is Dead at 76
description: With songs like “Margaritaville” and “Cheeseburger in Paradise,” he became a folk hero to fans known as Parrot Heads. He also became a millionaire hundreds of times over.
content: Jimmy Buffett, the singer, songwriter, author, sailor and entrepreneur whose roguish brand of island escapism on hits like “Margaritaville” and “Cheeseburger in Paradise” made him something of a latter-day folk hero, especially among his devoted following of so-called Parrot Heads, died on Friday. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Don’t Underestimate Jimmy Buffett’s Influence on Style
description: The singer made a lot of money peddling laid-back boatyard chic.
content: Odds are the world of capital-F fashion never gave a moment’s thought to Jimmy Buffett, the bard of Margaritaville, who died on Friday at 76. Yet the truth is the undisputed king of easy-listening yacht rock probably exerted as much influence on style as any designer that ever sent a model down a runway in a jacket with three sleeves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Aug. 26-Sept. 1
description: “Honey” easily attracted Bee adherents, but players had only isolated success with “abbacy.”
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Maggie Shannon
title: A California Beach Town Is Desperate to Save Its Vanishing Sand
description: Sea-level rise and man-made projects have left Oceanside with precious little beach space. That’s a problem if coastal life is part of your city’s identity.
content: In Oceanside, a coastal suburb about 40 miles north of San Diego, the palm trees sway and the temperature is almost always perfect. Fishermen cast their lines from the long, wooden pier. Teenagers with salt-bleached hair watch surfers ride glassy waves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: A Ship That Sank in 1881 Is Found Nearly Intact in Lake Michigan
description: Trinidad, built in 1867, was part of the lucrative grain trade on the Great Lakes. Its remarkably intact wreckage, which included stacks of dishes, was just discovered.
content: On the early morning of May 11, 1881, Capt. John Higgins and his eight-man crew scurried onto a lifeboat and caught a final glimpse of their schooner, Trinidad, as it disappeared into the icy waters of Lake Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: When Coco Gauff and Zendaya Need Tennis Tips, They Ask Brad Gilbert
description: Gilbert, a former pro, coached Andre Agassi to a U.S. Open victory in 1994. Now he’s advising Gauff — in between calling matches — at this year’s tournament.
content: Brad Gilbert — tennis junkie, junkballer, commentator, coach of legends — had roughly seven minutes to trade his coaching hat for a microphone, to shift from helping Coco Gauff manage her third-round match Friday night to interviewing Novak Djokovic in the tunnel before his.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Venice Film Festival: All Your Questions About Bradley Cooper’s ‘Maestro’ Answered
description: After a teaser set off controversy over the nose of main character Leonard Bernstein, the film finally premieres in Italy. Here’s what you need to know.
content: During a 1976 lecture at Harvard University, the conductor and composer Leonard Bernstein said, “A work of art does not answer questions, it provokes them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ziegler
title: The Season’s Hottest Accessory: The Honey Deuce Cup
description: Tennis fans stack, stash and take home the collectible cup after downing the U.S. Open’s signature cocktail.
content: Sometimes it sits alone on a table at the U.S. Open or in the grip of a thirsty tennis fan. Often it is stacked, maybe in a pair, maybe in a precariously balanced tower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: One Last Chance to Be Lazy
description: Loafers and idlers, including the heads of the Lazy Butt Club, extol the virtues of the not-so-busy life, even as many big companies start cracking down on return-to-office policies.
content: Early afternoon, late summer. Humid, 83 degrees. The cicadas were whirring outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: A Nation With Few Catholics Gives Pope a Welcome Fit for an Emperor
description: Mongolia put its history and culture on display as Pope Francis visited the Asian nation. Although it was the first trip to the country by a Roman Catholic pontiff, he noted that the two entities have ties dating back many centuries.
content: In a lush valley in the vast Mongolian countryside, hulking wrestlers, equestrians doing bareback tricks, throat singers and archers performed for top Vatican cardinals who snacked on dried yogurt delicacies under the shade of a ceremonial blue tent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
title: Quietly Crushing a Democracy: Millions on Trial in Bangladesh
description: The most active rivals to the country’s ruling party face dozens, even hundreds, of court cases each, paralyzing the opposition as a crucial election approaches.
content: Bangladesh’s multiparty democracy is being methodically strangled in crowded courtrooms across this country of 170 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas, Michael D. Shear and Jonathan Swan
title: DeSantis and Biden Won’t Meet in Florida During Tour of Hurricane Damage
description: Though the president said earlier on Friday that he would see the governor on Saturday, Mr. DeSantis’s office said there were no plans for a meeting.
content: President Biden said on Friday that he would meet with Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Saturday during a visit to tour the aftermath of Hurricane Idalia, the Category 3 storm that hit the state’s Gulf Coast and swept across the Southeast this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Europe’s Boars Still Hold Radioactivity. What Surprised Scientists Is Why.
description: Some wild boar hunted in German forests have radiation levels that exceed the limit deemed safe for human consumption. New research suggests that it’s not just because of Chernobyl.
content: Although scientists have long known that flora and fauna in Central Europe still carry traces of radiation stemming from the 1986 meltdown at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in Ukraine, a new study on wild boars roaming the forests of Bavaria in southern Germany has turned up unexpected findings about the radiation present in their tissue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Thrillers Spiked With Terror, Dread and Melancholy
description: Three new books come in several shades of fear.
content: These books come in several shades of fear. Two are about missing women and the sisters desperate to find them, and the third features a strange invention that preys on people’s tenderest thoughts of the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Driverless Taxis Blocked Ambulance in Fatal Accident, San Francisco Fire Dept. Says
description: Two Cruise taxis delayed an ambulance carrying a car accident victim to a hospital, a department report said. The company said it was not at fault.
content: Two Cruise driverless taxis blocked an ambulance carrying a critically injured patient who later died at a hospital, a San Francisco Fire Department report said, in another incident involving self-driving cars in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Nobel Foundation Reverses Prize Ceremony Invite for Russia and Belarus
description: The foundation, which also excluded both countries last year because of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, retracted an invite after the move drew outrage.
content: The Nobel Foundation reversed course on Saturday and said it would not invite the ambassadors of Russia and Belarus to the Nobel Prize award ceremony, acknowledging that an earlier decision to extend invitations had prompted backlash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Jimmy Buffett Was More Than Beaches and Booze
description: There was wistfulness behind party tunes like “Margaritaville.” Buffett helped listeners feel like they’d earned the good times just by holding on.
content: Jimmy Buffett built a pop-culture empire on the daydream of “wastin’ away again in Margaritaville”: just hanging out on a tropical beach, drink in hand, a little wistful but utterly relaxed. The empire’s cornerstone was his 1977 hit “Margaritaville,” a catalog of minor mishaps — a misplaced saltshaker, a cut foot — that were all easily soothed with “that frozen concoction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg and Karsten Moran
title: The Hardest Ticket at the U.S. Open? Ball Person.
description: The road to becoming a U.S. Open ball person is not for the faint of heart.
content: Thirty minutes before the gates to Arthur Ashe Stadium opened at 4 p.m. on June 22, a cluster of people began gently rolling tennis balls across a parking lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon, Lynsey Chutel and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Officials in South Africa Knew About Problems at a ‘Bad Building,’ but Did Nothing
description: An extensive paper trail reveals that the authorities in Johannesburg were warned repeatedly about the dangers in the derelict building where 76 people died in a fire this week.
content: No one was in the dark about what was happening at 80 Albert Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Austin
title: Welcome to Sweaty, Angry Midlife. Here’s Your Sullen Teenager!
description: Fran Littlewood’s debut novel, “Amazing Grace Adams,” takes readers on a tour of a mother’s darkest hour.
content: During one light-bulb moment in “Amazing Grace Adams,” the title character wonders which of her emotions are real and which are the fault of hormones gone awry. “It’s impossible to tell where the perimenopause stops and she begins,” writes Fran Littlewood, “and she’s asking herself who she would be if it wasn’t for those chemical enemies raging through her body, hijacking her mind, who she would be if her self had not come apart from her. She imagines she’d be nailing life, sailing through serenely.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Taxes, Drugs and … TikTok?
description: How one of Montana’s top elected officials made banning the app a top priority, putting the state at the center of a geopolitical storm.
content: On a recent summer day, Austin Knudsen, Montana’s attorney general, drove his red Buick from Helena, the state’s capital, to Boulder, a tiny town about a half-hour away whose main claim to fame is that it’s home to the state’s highway patrol. The road was quiet, flanked by the sort of sprawling pastures and expansive landscapes that give Montana its nickname of Big Sky Country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Struggles to Make ‘Bidenomics’ a Plus, Not a Minus
description: Wages are up, inflation has slowed and the White House has a new slogan. Still, President Biden’s poor marks on the economy are making Democrats worried.
content: When a chant slamming President Biden spread from a NASCAR race to T-shirts and bumper stickers across red America two years ago, the White House pulled off perhaps its savviest messaging feat to date. Biden aides and allies repackaged the “Let’s Go Brandon” insult and morphed it into “Dark Brandon,” a celebratory meme casting Mr. Biden as some sort of omnipotent mastermind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kira Thurman
title: How Classical Composers Made Music After the Holocaust
description: In “Time’s Echo,” the classical music critic Jeremy Eichler examines the life and work of Richard Strauss, Arnold Schoenberg, Benjamin Britten and Dmitri Shostakovich.
content: In 1947, the Black German musician Fasia Jansen stood on a street in Hamburg and began to sing the music of Brecht in her thick Low German accent to anyone passing by. Perhaps she’d learned the songs from prisoners and internees at Neuengamme, the concentration camp where she’d been forced to work four years earlier. Perhaps she’d learned them in the early days after the war, when she’d performed with Holocaust survivors at a hospital in 1945. One thing was clear: As Jansen wrestled with her trauma, song was at the center of her experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Why Charter and Disney Are Fighting, and What It Means for Viewers
description: Millions of subscribers to Charter’s Spectrum service cannot watch the U.S. Open or college football games this weekend, and the dispute has far-reaching implications for the industry.
content: Messy negotiations between the cable giant Charter Communications and the Walt Disney Company, which owns channels including ESPN and FX, prompted Charter on Friday to proclaim that the business model for cable TV was fundamentally broken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Preston Gannaway
title: I Spent 17 Years Photographing One Family’s Grief and Growth
description: The St. Pierre family has taught me everything I know about storytelling and intimacy.
content: Rich St. Pierre was 7 years old when his mother died suddenly. Well-meaning adults would tell him that “she had gone to a better place.” What, he wondered, was better than home, with him and his siblings? As he grew up, he had hardly any memories and only a few photos of his mother. Eventually, she faded away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Coco Gauff Wobbles, Then Steals the Show at the U.S. Open
description: Gauff, the 19-year-old American star, made error after error in the first set but rallied for a 3-6, 6-3, 6-0 win to advance to the round of 16.
content: In the opening set of her third-round match against Elise Mertens on Friday, Coco Gauff looked fallible, frustrated and like she would be finished early, nothing like she had earlier this week at the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Aaron Byrd, Chris Buckley and Pablo Robles
title: How Xi Returned China to One-Man Rule
description: For decades, China built guardrails to prevent another Mao. Here’s how Xi Jinping has dismantled them and created his own machinery of power.
content: For decades, China built guardrails to prevent another Mao. Here’s how Xi Jinping has dismantled them and created his own machinery of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helmuth Rosales and Geoff Macdonald
title: Seen from Close-up: How the U.S. Open Dials in its Court Speed
description: The tiny granules of sand that make up the hardcourt surfaces at Flushing Meadows shape the outcome of every match.
content: The tiny granules of sand that make up the hardcourt surfaces at Flushing Meadows shape the outcome of every match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Heavy Rain Drenches the Las Vegas Valley Area
description: Parts of the Las Vegas Strip and surrounding areas were inundated by thunderstorms as floodwaters filled the streets and flowed through a storm drain.
content: Parts of the Las Vegas Strip and surrounding areas were inundated by thunderstorms as floodwaters filled the streets and flowed through a storm drain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: DeSantis Snubs Biden During Tour of Hurricane Damage in Florida
description: President Biden said he was not disappointed that Gov. Ron DeSantis did not meet with him while he toured an area in Florida hit by Hurricane Idalia.
content: President Biden said he was not disappointed that Gov. Ron DeSantis did not meet with him while he toured an area in Florida hit by Hurricane Idalia.
source.name: The New York Times
